#T_RL=webanno.custom.Coref|type|BT_webanno.custom.Referent
#Text=Daly explained how she obtained these images of the anemone 's anatomy .
#Text=Image : Daly et al.

#Text=Just knowing a whole lot about a single species is n't very useful , even if that animal is as special as these clearly are — we need to know what about them is different and thus related to living in this strange way .
#Text=The only way to get at what 's different is to make comparisons with close relatives .
#Text=We can start that side of the work now , anticipating having more beasts in the future .
#Text=In terms of their glow , I suspect that it 's not theirs — although luminescence is common in anemone relatives , they do n't usually make light themselves .
#Text=They do make a host of florescent proteins , and these may interact with the light of the ROV to give that gorgeous glow .
#Text=( (
#Text=Wikinews
#Text=) )
#Text=What analysis did you perform on the specimens and what equipment was used ?
#Text=MD
#Text=I used a dissecting scope to look at the animal 's external anatomy and overall body organization ( magnification of 60X ) .

#Text=I embedded a few of the animals in wax and then cut them into very thin slices using a microtome , mounted the slices on microscope slides , stained the slices to enhance contrast , and then looked at those slides under a compound microscope ( that 's how I got the pictures of the muscles etc in the paper ) .
#Text=I used that same compound scope to look at squashed bits of tissue to see the stinging capsules ( = nematocysts ) .
#Text=I compared the things I saw under the ' scopes to what had been published on other species in this group .
#Text=This step seems trivial , but it is really the most important part !

#Text=By comparing my observations to what my colleagues and predecessors had found , I figured out what group it belongs to , and was able to determine that within that group , it was a new species .
#Text=( (
#Text=Wikinews
#Text=) )
#Text=It was three years between recovery of specimens and final publication , why did it take so long ?
#Text=MD
#Text=You mean , how did we manage to make it all happen so quickly , right ? : )
#Text=It was about two years from when Frank sent me specimens to when we got the paper out .
#Text=Some of that time was just lost time — I had other projects in the queue that I needed to finish .

#Text=Once we figured out what it was , we played a lot of manuscript email tag , which can be challenging and time consuming given the differing schedules that folks keep in terms of travel , field work , etc.
#Text=Manuscript review and processing took about four months .
#Text=( (
#Text=Wikinews
#Text=) )
#Text=What sort of difficulties were posed by the unorthodox preservatives used , and what additional work might be possible on a specimen with intact DNA ?
